large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Mole Catches the Sky

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (mole, light).
Begin Story Time by asking, How do the animals try to catch the sky?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, with a focus on counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Investigate and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children place and count Connecting Cubes in a 5-frame to represent friends at Mole’s house.
Guide children to say how many more friends can fit without counting them individually.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Who works together in this book?
Pretend you are with your friends in the kitchen. What are you making?
Make groups of five objects. Count them different ways. Does it matter what order you count in?
Why would you want to catch the sky?
Create a beautiful picture of the sky.
Use your finger to trace the letter s for sky.
Build an underground home, like Mole’s.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Mole Catches the Sky

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder showing empathy and caring and introduce vocabulary (caring).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Mole Catches the Sky .
Read closely to discover how characters show that they care for one another and to review cardinality.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5; Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children share a number of Two-Color Counters with a partner.
Guide children to tell how many counters their partner shared without counting.
Help children count to check their answers.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the people in this book show that they care?
Pretend your house is underground. What will you do in your house?
Make groups with five or less objects. Tell how many are in each group without counting. Count to check your answer.
Write about how you can tell if someone cares about you.
Make something to give to someone else. It should show that you care about them.
Trace the word mole with your finger. Count the number of letters in the word.
Work with a friend to build a tall tower.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2014 by Ellen Tarlow. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Star Bright Books, Inc. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Mole Catches the Sky

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, practice counting, and introduce vocabulary (underground, capture).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Mole Catches the Sky and asking, What do the animals try to bring Mole?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review counting.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5; Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children use Connecting Cubes to represent Mole and her friends, telling how many are inside and outside her home.
Guide children to count in sequential order to check their answers.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is light important in this book?
How would your game be different if you were playing it underground?
How can you count these objects? Would you count these other objects the same way?
Write a story about an animal who lives underground.
Why did you choose those materials to work with today?
Use the letters to spell out frog.
Build a tree that a squirrel can crawl up to get closer to the sky.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2014 by Ellen Tarlow. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Star Bright Books, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: We Have Soup!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice subitizing, talk about different types of vegetables, and introduce vocabulary (soup, peas).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts We Have Soup! and Mole Catches the Sky.
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question, What can we do better together?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5; Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use category words.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Use digital learning applications and programs.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children place a certain number of manipulatives into a soup as “vegetables.”
Ask children to say how many vegetables they have left without counting.
Discuss heat energy.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the characters help each other in the story?
Pretend to go to the grocery store. What do you need to buy to make soup?
What can you name that makes light or heat?
What is your favorite food to put in your soup?
Make a container that you would use to catch part of the sky. What part of the sky would you put in it?
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of soup?
Use blocks to make a building with a window on top.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2014 by Ellen Tarlow. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Star Bright Books, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Mole Catches the Sky

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to physical science, engage children with an activity, and build vocabulary by discussing opposites.
Start Story Time revisiting the book Mole Catches the Sky and asking, How do the animals work together?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and to review counting.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Understand and use a growing number of opposites.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Write a story about five animal friends working together.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book would you like to read next?
Pretend a friend is sick. What can you do to show that you care about them?
Make groups of objects. Count them forward and then backward.
Imagine you could catch the sky! Write about the part you would catch and how you’d catch it.
Design your own window. How much light will it let into the room?
Circle the two letters in window that are the same.
Work together to build a home. How many windows does your home have?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2014 by Ellen Tarlow. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Star Bright Books, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use concrete models or share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting zero to five objects from a set.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Use a variety of words to describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy.
Use concrete models or share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting zero to five objects from a set.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from one to five.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Use a variety of words to describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from one to five.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary, and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from one to five.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Increase listening vocabulary, and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Open and navigate through digital learning applications and programs.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy, including light, heat, and electricity.
